prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user wants to know if the author is in the wrong for leaving their fiancé after seven years because he's been in contact with another girl. The author has a child with the fiancé.

First, I need to break down the situation. They were together for seven years, had a kid. Broke up briefly three years ago, then got back together. The author expected the fiancé to cut contact with this girl he's known all his life. But even after conflicts, the fiancé continued to interact with her on social media. The author snooped and found evidence of ongoing likes and interactions. Confronted him, he got angry but said he'd stop. Then later, the author found more likes, including the girl's sister. The fiancé claimed it was accidental. Now, recently, the author found the girl and her sister unblocked again. So the author left him.

The main question is whether the author is in the wrong. The key points here are about trust, boundaries in a relationship, and evidence of ongoing contact despite promises. The author felt justified because they had evidence of repeated breaches of trust, even if there's no proof of cheating. The fiancé's actions suggest a pattern of not respecting the author's boundaries, which might have eroded trust over time.

In relationships, especially long-term ones, maintaining trust and respecting each other's boundaries is crucial. If one partner repeatedly violates those boundaries, even without cheating, it can be a valid reason to end the relationship. The author did confront the fiancé multiple times, and he made promises he didn't keep. The fact that he had to unblock them again shows intent, maybe. The author's decision to leave after consistent issues seems reasonable. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
